{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Linda Smith | image = Linda Smith (comedian).jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Linda Helen Smith | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1958|1|29}} | birth_place = [[Erith]],<!-- Do not change to London, Erith was in Kent in 1958 --> Kent, England<ref name="BBC Obituary">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4759922.stm |title=Entertainment | Obituary: Linda Smith |publisher=BBC News |date=28 February 2006 |accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2006|2|27|1958|1|29}} | death_place = [[Wrotham]], Kent, England | occupation = Comedian | nationality = British | height = | years_active = 1987–2006 | parents = | relatives = | spouse = Warren Lakin }} '''Linda Helen Smith''' (29 January 1958 – 27 February 2006) was an English comedian and comedy writer. She appeared regularly on [[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]] panel games, and was voted "Wittiest Living Person" by listeners in 2002. She met her partner, Warren Lakin, at university, and they were together for nearly 30 years until her death.
==Life and career== Smith was born in [[Erith]] in Kent<!-- Do not change to London, Erith was in Kent in 1958 --> in 1958 and was educated at Erith College of Technology (now [[Bexley College]]) and at the [[University of Sheffield]] where she graduated in English and Drama. She joined a professional theatre company before turning to comedy.<ref name="BBC Obituary"/> In 1987, she won the [[Hackney Empire New Act of the Year]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.funny.co.uk/news/art_75-1940-Peter-Aterman-voted-New-Act-of-the-Year-2004.html |title=Peter Aterman voted New Act of the Year 2004 | Funny.co.uk – UK Comedy Site |publisher=Funny.co.uk |date= |accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> then known as the New London Comic Award, and performed on the Edinburgh Fringe before breaking into radio comedy.
Many of her early stand-up appearances were benefit concerts staged in solidarity with the British miners during the [[Miners strike|Miners' Strike]] in the 1980s. She was a lifelong socialist.
Her first appearances on national radio were on Radio 5's ''The Treatment'' in 1997. She was subsequently a regular panellist on ''[[The News Quiz]]'' and ''[[Just a Minute]]'' and appeared frequently on ''[[I'm Sorry I Haven't a Clue]]'' (from June 2001 onwards), ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', ''[[Mock the Week]]'', ''[[Countdown (game show)|Countdown]]'' and ''[[QI]]''. She wrote and starred in her own Radio 4 sitcom, ''[[Linda Smith's A Brief History of Timewasting]]''. After appearing on Radio 4's ''Devout Sceptics'' to discuss her beliefs she was asked by the [[British Humanist Association]] (BHA) to become president of the society, a role that she occupied with commitment from 2004 until her death.<ref name="humanist">[http://www.humanism.org.uk/site/cms/newsarticleview.asp?article=2161 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061016212851/http://www.humanism.org.uk/site/cms/newsarticleview.asp?article=2161 |date=16 October 2006 }}</ref> In 2002, she was voted 'Wittiest Living Person' by listeners to BBC Radio 4's ''Word of Mouth''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2002/05_may/30/linda_smith.shtml |title=Press Office – Linda Smith |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> In his 2003 book Classic Radio Comedy, Mat Coward called Smith "the funniest woman on radio today".<ref>Coward, Mat, ''Classic Radio Comedy'', (2003), p. 79. Cox & Wyman.</ref>
On 17 November 2003, Smith appeared on the [[BBC]] television show ''[[Room 101 (TV series)|Room 101]]'', where she successfully managed to put in "adults who read [[Harry Potter]] books", [[Tim Henman]], "Back to School signs that appear in shops" and "posh people". However, she failed to put in [[Bow ties]] after host [[Paul Merton]] pointed out that [[Stan Laurel]] regularly wore a bow tie.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/room_101/episodes/8/3/ |title=Room 101 - Episode 8.3. Linda Smith - British Comedy Guide |publisher=Comedy.co.uk |date=2003-11-17 |accessdate=2015-04-23}}</ref>
==Illness, death and legacy== On 27 February 2006, Smith died as a consequence of [[ovarian cancer]] at the age of 48.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4759968.stm |title=Entertainment | Radio comedian Linda Smith dies |publisher=BBC News |date=28 February 2006 |accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> She had been diagnosed with ovarian cancer three and a half years earlier but, not wanting to be thought of as a patient or a victim, she did not want people to know.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hardy |first=Jeremy |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4760038.stm |title=Entertainment | 'Her mind was extraordinary' |publisher=BBC News |date=28 February 2006 |accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> Before she died she chose that her funeral be [[humanism|humanist]]<ref name="indie">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/linda-smith-god-the-biggest-joke-of-all-468233.html |title=Linda Smith: God, the biggest joke of all – Profiles – People |publisher=The Independent |date=2 March 2006 |accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> and her memorial at the [[Theatre Royal, Stratford East]], on 10 March,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.funny.co.uk/news/art_76-4097-An-Evening-of-Linda-Smiths-Favourite-Things.html |title=An Evening of Linda Smith's Favourite Things | Funny.co.uk – UK Comedy Site |publisher=Funny.co.uk |date= |accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> was dedicated to the [[British Humanist Association|BHA]]. Her life and work were honoured at the [[British Academy Television Awards 2006|British Academy Television Awards]] in 2006. The first episode of [[Dawn French]]'s ''[[Dawn French's Girls Who Do Comedy|Girls Who Do: Comedy]]'' was dedicated to the memory of Linda Smith. A tribute edition of ''The News Quiz'' featuring clips of Linda's appearances and personal memories of her from other panellists was broadcast on BBC Radio 4 on 3 March 2006, hosted by [[Simon Hoggart]].
Two tribute gigs were held in her memory. The first took place on 14 May 2006 at the [[Lyceum Theatre (Sheffield)|Lyceum Theatre, Sheffield]], ''In Praise of an English Radical'', the second on 4 June 2006 at the [[Victoria Palace Theatre]] in London entitled ''Tippy Top: An Evening of Linda Smith's Favourite Things''. In August 2006, [[Andy Hamilton]] presented a [[BBC Radio 4]] tribute entitled ''Linda Smith: A Modern Radio Star''. An anthology on CD, entitled ''I Think the Nurses Are Stealing My Clothes: The Very Best of Linda Smith'', was released in November 2006 as was a book with the same name. A tribute show of the same name was aired on BBC Radio 4 on 10 November 2006. Smith's sell-out stage show ''Wrap Up Warm'' has been available on CD since November 2006.
Linda Smith was working on a third series of ''A Brief History of Timewasting'' before she became incapacitated by her illness. As a tribute the online radio station [[BBC 7]] ran the previous two series, the first all on one day.
The University of Kent holds The Linda Smith Collection as the foundation of the British Stand-Up Comedy Archive. It includes notes, diaries, scripts, audio-visual recordings, photographs, press cuttings, correspondence and publicity material covering her entire life and career. It was deposited at the University of Kent by Linda's partner Warren Lakin in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kent |first=University of |url=https://www.kent.ac.uk/library/specialcollections/standupcomedy/linda-smith/ |title=Information Systems | 'Special Collections' |publisher=University of Kent |date=31 December 2013 |accessdate=31 March 2017}}</ref>
